titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Frederick Douglass Letter and autograph, 1875-1880
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, September 2018

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: A Douglass autograph and a letter from Douglass to Pinckney Benton Stewart Pinchback, 1875 July 16, mentioning a meeting to be held as a preliminary to the Republican National Convention of 1876. Douglass writes, "With the immense political power now in our hands, if wisely exercised, the colored people of this country need not fail to have all their rights respected nor fail to secure a respectable and proportionate representation both in the states and in the nation."

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Frederick Douglass letter and autograph, 1875-1880, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, September 2018.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: A Douglass autograph and a letter from Douglass to Pinckney Benton Stewart Pinchback, 1875 July 16, mentioning a meeting to be held as a preliminary to the Republican National Convention of 1876. Douglass writes, "With the immense political power now in our hands, if wisely exercised, the colored people of this country need not fail to have all their rights respected nor fail to secure a respectable and proportionate representation both in the states and in the nation."
